text: CLOSE on the needle of a precision-weighted 33rpm turntab It comes down, touches vinyl. The Rolling Stones "Sympath for the Devil" purrs out... ARTHUR BISHOP (40's) Sitting in a comfortable wooden chai stares right through us. Lean, hard, in perfect physical shape. In this moment, carrying the stillness of someone utterly in balance. For all we know, he's been sitting th way for hours.

Every man has a death that's right for him. Every one. REVERSE to find a wall of photographs, charts, official documents. In the center A PHOTOGRAPH of a man, mid-40's, East-Indian, dressed like the billionaire he is. Dodi Fay meets Bill Gates. THE MARK.

For every man, there's a way to leave this earth which is so right for them, it's almost as if they carry it with them. MOVING over the wall. MORE PHOTOGRAPHS. The Mark escorted from a bullet-proof sedan by ear-wired men. Entertaining a palatial estate. Magazine covers: "The billion-dollar lifestyle." "The new Playboy." ...passing over smaller articles: "What does this man do with your money?"

When the right death overtakes a man, there will be grief in those who knew him, but there will also be a sense of inevitability. Because they will know, that of course... CLOSE ON BISHOP. Statue-like, except his eyes which dart across the wall in front of him, making connections...
VINTAGE RACE CARS speed by, a blur of color. But all we h is the Rolling Stones' song. And...

...Of course, this was always going to happen this way. WHOMP! The SOUND OF THE RACE floods in as the cars blow b revealing Bishop amidst onlookers, watching, calculating. 2. BISHOP'S P.O.V.: Two cars TANGLE in a corner, SPIN to a stop, crushing a half-million in beautiful restored antiq The Mark climbs from his wreck, tosses his helmet, pissed Bishop raises a camera, takes a picture.

Bishop at his wall again, this time actively engaged, wor it. A picture of the Mark in his vintage car goes up, underneath, Bishop tacks a stats page: "Fatality in auto accidents by type of impact. Head on, Side rear,..." Off to the side, bank statements, cash transfers. Saudi Arabia. Chechnya. United Arab Emirates. Bishop tacks more photos up. The Mark, getting off a priv plane, the Mark, playing Polo...

WHACK! A Rider SLAMS a ball forward, spurs his horse onwards, bearing down on the ball... and SLAM! Another Ri comes in from the side, sends the man crashing off his ho The second man, the Mark, takes a second to gloat over hi fallen opponent before CHARGING onwards. IN THE STANDS. Bishop watches, takes a note on a pad.

Bishop keeps working, the wall completely covered now. Li of possible deaths have been ordered, drawbacks circled. Bishop scans over various magazine covers featuring the M One with a vintage hunting rifle slung low in his arms, unbroken. "American Dream or American Nightmare?" Bishop stares at this. Eyes moving over the wall, acciden stats, a copy of a hunting-club reprimand... he's arrived

Bishop stands in front of a moving riverway, his body sheathed in a black slicksuit, backpack on. He slips into the water and starts to SWIM. We STAY with Bishop as he SWIMS HARD, powerfully, not tir Finally, we PULL AWAY, across miles of water, realizing t is what Bishop will swim without stopping. 3.

A pair of ARMED SECURITY patrol a wooded shore. One lifts pair of binoculars, scans the shore as BEHIND THEM, a for moves from behind a tree, blends into the woods. ON BISHOP. Moving fast, silent, towards a LIT STRUCTURE i the distance...

BLACK. The SENSE that someone is in here with us... A LOW GREEN GLOW illuminates Bishop in a TINY, CRAMPED, COMPARTMENT. No way to know what or where. The glow, comi from his watch, illuminates his face, crammed and claustrophobic. An eye checks the time, the light goes ou Just the sound of his breathing...

CRACK! CRACK! PLUMES OF SMOKE rise from the end of vintag hunting rifles. Game birds scatter into the air. Dogs BAR tear through underbrush. MEN dressed in traditional hunti livery move through foggy woods, followed by STEWARDS. This is old school hunting, old school weapons. Camera fi The Mark, raising his weapon, sights... BLAM! A PHEASANT falls, dogs race after it. The Mark starts forward but is interrupted by his Steward reminding him to break his wea as the other hunters have. The Mark pushes the man back, ignoring him, hurrying on. a small distance, two unhappy private security guards fol
BLACKNESS. A soft BEEPING, almost inaudible. A low rustle of cloth, then the green glow illuminates Bishop's face a checks the time again. Hasn't moved in HOURS.

The Mark stumbles forward, over-eager to get to his prize He's worked his way ahead of the field. The MIST has grow thicker. Human forms move on all sides, hard to distingui CRACK! CRACK! Guns go off around them. Dogs rush by. The Mark brings the weapon to his face... BLAM!! The shot ech through the foggy woods. 4.

The Mark, pleased with himself as always, bursts into the lodge, gun over his shoulder. A round of APPLAUSE as his Steward holds up the morning's catch. He pushes on into the locker rooms as one security takes station at the door. The second emerges from the lockers, having just done his sweep.

The Mark leans his vintage hunting rifle against the wall opens his locker. He kicks off his boots, pulls off his shirt. Takes a second to rub his face with his hands. It can be exhausting being him. Behind the Mark, a locker door opens and closes. Like a ghost did it. He doesn't sense a thing, reaches for his weapon, accidentally knocks it to the side. It LANDS, HAR The Mark WINCES, half expecting it to fire. But no. He starts to lean down for it when another man's gloved h reach it first. The Mark smiles down at the well-dressed crouched by the gun, a little confused. Bishop looks up, smiles back. He puts out a gloved hand. Before the Mark can consider, he's taken Bishop's hand. Bishop holds tight. The Mark's smile... fades. Even though we know it's coming, Bishop's actions are so and final we're taken by surprise. He PULLS the Mark in a at the same time he cocks the rifle's hammer, slams the g into position, barrel pointed up and BOOM! The shot hits the Mark in the face, obliterates him, send plume of gore up against the ceiling. One, two seconds before the Mark's SECURITY rush into the room, guns lined. First sees the mess, puts a hand to his mouth. Second starts on the radio. The room is empty.

A vintage 1972 Shelby Cobra parked by the edge of the riv Bishop emerges from the water, pops the trunk of the car. Towel and large rock inside. He towels off, tosses the su and the rock into his pack, pack goes into the river. He grabs a sweater from inside the trunk. 5.
Bishop gets behind the wheel, dressed. He checks himself the rearview, finds a bead of sweat traveling from his br Wipes it away, irritated, and starts the car.
Establishing. A quaint local convenience store off a two- lane road, nestled amidst trees. Bishop's vintage car pul up and he gets out.
Door jingles as Bishop steps in, smiles to the GROCER, a friendly beefy guy in his 60's who checks the clock. 7:00 the nose.

'Evening, Arthur. Got your weekly right here. The man hoists two bags of groceries onto the counter. Bishop comes forward, sees the Owner's DAUGHTER behind th counter. 12, precocious, reading a dog-eared kid's book.

Hey, Sophie. I got something for you, wanna see? The girl smiles, puts down the book and comes over. Bisho crouches in front of her. He puts out two empty hands, sh them back and front, then tickles one ear with a hand whi the other "appears" a small daisy. The girl sees it, smiles... a little disappointed.

I'm just kidding. Bishop reaches into his jacket, pulls out the next installment in the kid's book she's reading: A series featuring a young female Harry-Potter like character on t cover: LUNA CROMWELL. Sophie BEAMS, takes it. A quick hug and she's back to her seat, opening the new book.
What do you say, honey?
Thank you, Bishop. 6.
You're very welcome. And she's back into the book. Bishop smiles, a little sad It was nice... but the moment's over. He stands and colle his groceries.
See you next week, Arthur.

A ranch-style compound, nestled in the hills. Warm, rusti and inviting. Bishop's Cobra drives past the MAIN HOUSE, a large crafts into a BARN where he parks next to a collection of other beautiful vintage cars. He gets out, crosses the dirt dri towards his home. A STUDIO separate from the main house. Two horses graze in an attached paddock.

Bishop's enters, flicking on lights. The home is beautifu ordered. Everything a model of design and elegance. The walls are home to a collection of original and slightly sociopathic art. Lucian Freud, de Chirico, Zak Smith, Francis Bacon. Isolation, beauty, unrest...

Bishop unpacks his groceries. Organic. Raw. Supplements. Vitamins. Nothing looks delicious. His fridge is ordered. Glass containers in rows, lightly hued liquids in each. He opens a can of Friskies, sets it down for a mutt-like tabby-cat who lopes over and eats. Bishop scratches her behind the ears.

Bishop flicks on lights illuminating the WALL covered wit charts, documents, photographs of the Mark. He goes to a gas fireplace built into the side of the roo fires up the flames. A sideboard holds a collection of Vi Albums. Mint condition, collector. Fingers play over titles... Rolling Stones, Neil Young, Bob Dylan... The turntable needle hits Young's "Needle and the Damage Done." Music croons sweet into the room as pages, photos, everything goes into the fire. 7. One photo in particular: The Mark, busy on the phone as a young girl pulls at his suit jacket. He was a criminal bastard, but also a father. Bishop stares down at the picture, consumed by fire, reflected in his eyes.

Bishop, running on a treadmill, full-tilt. A controlled sprint without end. The gym has all manner of customized exercise equipment. Weights, machines, a climbing wall, a infinite lap-pool. Bishop jumps off the treadmill, immediately takes his pul checks it against a clock on the wall, jots a note. Bishop, pressing weights. 300+ pounds. Reps over and over Muscles HARD, STRAINING. In his eyes, almost a relaxed intensity. The rest of the world, turned off. Bishop RACKS the weights, LOUD. Immediately taking his pulse, checking the clock...

Bishop sits at a small desk, plotting the evening's work- in a book. He traces columns, enters points on a graph. THE BOOK. Doesn't matter how impressive the numbers are, they've peaked and are now starting their inevitable slid ON BISHOP. Staring at the book.
Bishops stands in front of his phone. He scrolls through last ten calls that have come through. They all read "McKenna, Harry." Over and over. Three days' worth.

Bishop eats dinner, alone at the end of a beautiful antiq table. Hanging on the wall across from him, a vivid disturbing painting of three women. ON HIS PLATE. His food is a meal we might expect an astronaut to eat. Raw Spinach, a collection of supplement He crunches through something that looks like cardboard, chews, stares at the painting. In his study, the phone rings. He eyeballs it, lets it ring. 8.

Bishop sits on the couch in front of the television, his curls under his arm, purring. Bishop flips channels throu an endless display of over-amped human behavior. People H and WINK in the sitcoms, people YELL on the talk-shows, people CRY and LUST on the dramas. Flip. Flip. A news channel shows a PICTURE of The Mark. "Billionaire mogul dead in tragic accident." Two ANCHORS discuss...

...here's a guy at the top of his game. And yes there were questions about the money: Where did it all go. Were some of his friends less than friendly to the US? But in the end, it's not the feds who catch up with him --
It's that age old adage that boys will be boys. These dangerous hobbies come with the risk of accidents like this -- Bishops punches off the tv, heads for the door.
Bishop pulls up in his car, looks up. Hundred of lit wind above him, lives going on behind each. He heads forward, doorman holding the door for him.
Bishop gets out of the elevator, stops in front of a door Beat. He rings the bell.
It's open! Bishop pushes the door open, steps into...

Beautifully, warmly furnished. Sofas surround a living ar a gas fire flickering. Throws and rugs. Art on the walls, tasteful and human. An open bottle of wine on a granite counter top. THE VIEW. Over all the city, thousands of lights twinkle. 9.

I'll just be a minute. We catch a GLIMPSE of the WOMAN. A towel over her hair, wearing a skirt and a bra, crossing from the bathroom int her bedroom. Even in the small glimpse, she's beautiful. Bishop looks down at a coffee table. Magazines, newspaper A picture of the first Mark's elaborate funeral.

I'm sorry I was away so long this time. I had some complications... He turns. She's emerged from the bedroom. 30's. Long dark hair, damp from the shower. Buttoning a shirt, the curve her breasts caught as she does. A comfortable, sophistica air about her. Effortlessly attractive.
You don't have to apologize. I'm just glad you're here now.
Are you hungry? She starts to move by him, his hand catches her arm and s is in his arms, holding him TIGHT, kissing him.
I'm sorry. I just... miss you. I never thought I was going to be a "woman who waits." But I do. I wait for you. He nods. She breaks off, pours red wine in a glass.
Were you in Europe? Africa?
Was there another woman?
No.

Liar. It's alright. I don't mind. (Suddenly shifting gears) I... I made something for you. She picks up a remote, fire up a large flatscreen TV. Hit button. A moment, then an IMAGE flickers to life. ON THE TV: The WOMAN, sitting in this same living room. S wears a long sleeve shirt over panties. Sips a glass of wine. Smiles warm at the camera. The silence of late nigh 10.
Hey, you. Just got back from the weekend at the lake with Julianne and Barry and their kids. Their oldest is five. You'd like him.

Everybody spoke about you, of course. We should go up there sometime, just the two of us... ON THE TV: She reaches towards the camera and the image JUMPS AHEAD. Another night, late. The WOMAN enters the frame, now wearing a stunning black party dress.

(announcing, giggling) I, just got back from seeing the most boring opening at the Pierre Grochet gallery. And of course everyone's asking where you are and of course I made your apologies, but what I was thinking... ON THE TV: She winks at the camera, happily drunk. Raises her dress a little, suggestive...

Why weren't you here to take me home and make love to me...? She blows a kiss. Closes her eyes... ON BISHOP: Watching. Emotion breaks the surface. The WOMAN raises the remote. Turns off the image. Looks a Bishop. Plain, not demanding. But caring.
I'm not a man who... It wouldn't be good for you, if I was around all the time.
I know. I know. She moves to him and they are kissing fierce.

Bishop and the woman make love. She's the aggressor at first, pulling away Bishop's clothing, climbing on top of him, pulling her own clothes away... 11. Bishop grabs the woman who LAUGHS in ecstacy. He reverses her, throwing her down on the bed, climbing on top. The t of them, eye to eye as they fuck...

Early morning light filters into the room. Bishop, awake, staring at the sleeping woman. His eyes click over to the clock which reaches 6:00 am. As if he's been waiting, Bis rises and dresses, silently.

Bishop stands in front of the plate glass windows. He tur and moves to a music box on a shelf, opens it. A melancho tune plays. He admires the machinery as he removes twenty $100 bills from his wallet, tucks them under the box...
Stay for breakfast? He turns. She's standing in the doorway, tying a robe aro herself. A cool professionalism inhabits her demeanor. No crass or mean-spirited, but the romance is gone.
Do I ever?
No. But there's a first time for everything. Bishop goes to the DVD player, slots out the DVD they wat the night before and pockets it.
Thank you. This was a good one. See you next time.
Bishop... You all right? He turns, studies her. This is new ground. He nods and leaves. She stares a moment at the door after he's gone.

Bishop, running. Full-tilt again, a maintained sprint. He maneuvers through trees, over rocks. Below him, through t woods, his home comes into view... ... a BLACK BENTLEY sits parked in front of the house. A on a cell phone stands by it. 12.
The man wears a mid-level suit, a hired professional.
(into a phone) Yes, I just got here. No, not yet. He turns, REACTS as Bishop is there, CLOSE, barely sweati
Hold on, I got him. The man holds his cell phone out for Bishop. A beat, Bish studying the angles... he takes the phone.
Arthur? Jesus Christ, Arthur, is that you?
...How are you, Harry?

Oh you know, I'm God Damn perfect. I'm redecorating my fucking office and I wanted your advice on the god forsaken curtains is how I am. (beat, serious) This is... this is something, Arthur. I need to see you, for old time's sake.

Bishop sits in the back, looks out at the city moving aro them as the man drives. They approach the armored gates o business tower: MCKENNA HOLDING CORP. The driver nods at SECURITY who recognize the car, open the gate. The car dr down into the garage under the building.
Bishop and the man exit the Bentley. Four more ARMED SECURITY down here, seated around a table, eating deliver from a local Deli. Two stand, one steps forward.
Sorry, gotta do this... Patient, Bishop puts his arms out as the man searches him 13.

Bishop steps out of the elevator into a top-level wonderl of money manipulation. Desks, crushed with monitors, mann by casually brilliant MIT-grads. Flat screens track the markets. All of this overseen by a witch's tit of a MANAG who eyeballs Bishop coolly. A tapping gets Bishop's attention. The corner office is glass-walled. HARRY MCKENNA is tapping on it, gesturing Bishop inside.

The office is high-tech. Harry less so. 60's. Overweight and doesn't give a shit. Cigars in a ashtray, ash-burns o the Persian rugs. A man to be reckoned with, in his time. The time has perhaps passed. Harry comes out from behind his desk, points Bishop to a leather sofa. Bishop perches on the arm.
I like the new digs. McKenna LAUGHS, like a grunt. Fiddles with his hearing ai turning it up. Bishop's eyes track.
Has it really been that long? Jesus.

You know how they say youth is lost on the young? They're right. If I had my nineteen year old body back, I wouldn't be here, I'll tell you that. I'd be out there, making it my personal life mission to bang every stewardess who ever dared put on one of those whatchamacallit skirts.
Times have changed, Harry. They don't wear skirts anymore. McKenna eyeballs Bishop, shakes his head. He goes to the glass wall, points out at the screens, financial markets.

You know what all that is? (off Bishop's nod) That's their money, getting moved, exchanged. Made clean and neat and proper for Uncle Sam. And I have always been extremely careful. 14. McKenna goes to his desk, tosses legal papers on the tabl between them.

You know what that is? That's a God damn subpoena from the Justice Department. We get a new face in the white house, all of a sudden they want to look at my records. They got accountants want to go through MY BOOKS. Are you kidding me? I got the left hand coming after me for what I did for the right hand. Bishop looks over the papers, nods.
So I call them up. I say "hey, you guys gotta get your own house in order..."
And...
And? And that's the point! Nothing. I tell them they have a problem here and instead of dealing with it I get silence, zippo, fuck- all. What are they, twelve?
...I don't see how I can --
That's bullshit, Arthur. Your father -- they still talk about the guy like he walked on water. You, they'll listen to. You --
I'm not a part of that. McKenna stares out the window at the street below, nervou Shakes a pill out of as small vial, pops it. He chuckles, shakes his head.

You remember that fishing trip we all took, back in the day. You were, what? About eight, right? (Off Bishop's nod) You fell out of the boat... couldn't swim a stroke. City kid. (Animated, laughing) You're in the water, splashing around.

You got these big eyes like saucers, like you're sure you're gonna drown. Splashing... swallowing water... just STARING at your father and he's not making a move. Remember? Just looking down at you like... Suddenly it's gotten less funny.
I finally had to grab you by the hair, pull you back into the boat. You're shivering like hell and he -- your dad -- gives one of those laughs. Those big laughs everyone loved him for.
Anyway, the whole time you're in the water, you didn't cry out. Not once. You were a tough sonofabitch, even then.
That was a long time ago, Harry. McKenna turns from the window, takes in all his monitors, charts. Stock lines tick up and down, graphs flow, pulse.

Well, I'm in the water this time, Arthur. You think it's easy for me to ask? It cuts like hell. But that's what I'm doing. Bishop eyes the barely open doorway into a small room off office. Pillows and blankets on a sofa. Some clothes stre about. McKenna's been sleeping here. A long beat. Bishop... nods. The tension seems to DRAIN from McKenna. He claps Bishop on the back, nods back.

...Thank you. Thank you. THROUGH THE GLASS WALL OF THE OFFICE. Bishop's eyes track elevator doors open and STEVE MCKENNA steps out, a beauti young woman with him, LOUISE. She's a trophy, the woman y get for being top dog and the one you regret getting. Gorgeous, self-obsessed, entitled. She flops onto a leath sofa as Steve moves towards the office. Steve's young, mid-20's, strikingly handsome, wearing the casual uniform of wealth not earned. But there's somethin else that arrests Bishop immediately. Unwasted motion, detachment, observing the world around him... from above. 16. Even as Steve nods to one of his father's security and pu into the room, he picks up Bishop. The two men lock eyes, strange reflection not of appearance, but of nature.
And here's the prodigal son, arrived to bilk me for ransom.
Steve, this is Arthur Bishop. Steve shakes Bishop's hand. Strong. Observant.
Hey. Nice to meet you. You work for my father?
No, quite the opposite. Arthur's doing me a little favor.
So you're a criminal?
That's enough.
Relax, relax. I'm kidding. A last beat between Steve and Bishop, then Steve lets it turns his attention to his father.
I need you to make a donation to Louise's charity. She's mounting some kind of fundraiser and she wants to make sure we do our part.
What's it for?
I have no idea. And don't pretend you care, either. Write the check, go to the party, smile when the
you and call you a great and generous man.
You ever think of having kids, Arthur?
Nope. 17. Wearily, McKenna brings out his checkbook.
Wise man. How much?

Thirty thousand. (Suddenly, to Bishop) You know, I can't tell what you're thinking, Mr. Bishop. Usually, I'm very good with that, with people. Sort of like a bullshit detector I developed. But you're very... hard to read.
Sorry.
Don't be. So what are you thinking?
I was thinking that a son, should be more grateful to his father.
I agree. I agree. I often wonder why I'm not. McKenna tears the check out, hands it to Steve.
There. Now go away.
Thank you, dad. Are we going to see you at the house any time soon?
Yeah, this is just a few more days. We got this... situation. Steve hears the dark in his father's tone, tracks it.
Anything I can do?
You? Yeah, you can earn some money. Get married.
No, it's going to be okay now. Arthur's helping me out. Steve glances between the two men. Ego slightly bruised. 18.

Well it's good to meet you Mr. Bishop. My father seems to trust you, which is... unusual. Bishop and McKenna watch as he hits the atrium, hands Lou the check who goes out of her mind, jumping up and down, giving him a kiss that speaks of more to come, trotting o Steve glances back one more time, then follows her.
We will take from our children for a lifetime what we would not suffer from another man for an instant. Explain that to me. (off Bishop's silence) Okay. Okay, call me when you hear something.
You take care of yourself, Harry.
Well, that's your job now, isn't it?
Bishop exits the elevator. Security holds the door to the Bentley open for him. Bishop shakes his head, walks out.

Bishop exits an old freight elevator, enters this HUGE lo space. Old architecture divided by free-standing walls hu with PAINTINGS from the same artist who's work hangs in Bishop's home. Intense, slightly surreal, deeply haunting Nudes, raw. Men's faces, distraught, alone. A matronly ART DEALER comes forward familiar, takes his h

Arthur. Glad you're here. Right this way. As they move across the space Bishop catches sight of a MODEL, lying nude in a pool of blue paint. Across from he The ARTIST is full-focused on her. He's roughly Bishop's age. Cigarette dangles off a lip, tattoos on his arms. Fully comfortable and committed to the alternative life. The model senses Bishop's gaze, looks over, unashamed. 19.
This way. Bishop follows the Dealer into another area where they approach a canvas. It's a portrait of a young boy, alone. The effect is of rage-filled isolation.
Zak is almost finished. It will make a wonderful addition to your collection. Bishop looks at the canvas. Nods. Glances back to where t artist is carefully adjusting his model's position.
Do you want to meet him?
Bishop enters his home, sets his things down. Stares at h phone a beat, then on impulse picks it up and dials. The voice that answers is female, official.
Good evening, Mr. Bishop. How can I help you?
Yes. I'd like to speak to Dean. There's a brief pause on the phone, then.
...Mr. Dean is not available right now. Can I take a message?

No. Just tell him I called. Bishop hangs up, stares at the phone. The doorbell rings. Bishop opens it to find a DHL COURIER his doorstep. Bishop is suddenly casual, friendly. The public face of Bishop.
Hello, Don. They make you drive all the way out here this evening?
That's the job. 20. The man gestures to the open barn door, the classic cars.
You find tires for that old FleetMaster?
No, not yet. Maybe when I do, we'll take it out for a spin. Say hello to the wife for me.

Will do. Good night, Arthur. The man heads back towards his truck. Bishop tears away t strip that seals the envelope, a small USB jump-drive sli into his hands. The friendly grin on Bishop's face... evaporates.

Bishop fires up a computer hooked to a printer. He slots USB drive into the computer. Nothing seems to happen, jus low pulsing red light on the drive. Almost instantly, his phone rings and he answers. Silence

We should all be so lucky. Click. The phone goes dead. Almost at the same time, the glowing red light on the jump-drive turns GREEN. Bishop's PRINTER fires up. It starts printing out pages. few medical charts... and then a photograph: Harry McKenn The new mark.
Bishop eats. Lost in thought. Eyes play over his art...

Bishop hits the study, work-mode. All hesitation gone. Pages are tacked up, other ripped down and tossed. He tak out a thick pen, circles words: "Syncope cardiac spasms.. "Prognosis..." "Poor eustachian tube function..." 21.

Bishop sits at a desk under a reading lamp, making notes of a stack of books. Medical textbooks. Charts. A diagram of the central nervous system. Stress tests. The technica specs for an electronic device.
Bishop receives a SET OF PLANS from an attendant. Spreads them out over a counter. In the corner, a large photocopi

Bishop sits at his desk, a Jeweler's Loup over one eye, working with soldering iron and electronic tools, meticul Behind him, tacked to the wall, are copies of the buildin plans. Heavily inked. Routes in and out penned in. Locations of security. Photographs. He's done his recon. Sitting in the sun on a window ledge: an open jar of Mayonnaise, turning rancid. A fly buzzes around it. THROUGH THE JEWELER'S LOUP: Bishop is working on a hearin aide. Tweezers adjust a tiny chip, slot it into place... Phone rings. Bishop eyes it for a beat. Snaps it up. The voice on the other end is world weary, professional. DEAN
Bishop. I heard you called. Hey, you get the stuff I sent you?
That's what I called about. I know him. I think there might be a
Hold on a second. A long pause. Just air on the line. Bishop stares at his work in front of him, his research on McKenna tacked to t wall. Dean's voice comes back as suddenly as it departed.
No, it's been decided. This one's a go. You take care of yourself, Bishop. The line goes dead. Bishop stares at the phone for a seco sets it down. He looks up at Harry's picture on the wall. 22.
The sun rises over the city, shafts of light illuminating top floor plate glass of McKenna Holding Corp. The SOUND A PHONE RINGING, being picked up.
Hello?
They want to talk. I'm picking you up in an hour.
Send your people home. I don't want anyone I don't know near you today. I'm serious.
...Thank you, Arthur.

Bishop hangs up his phone, watches as three bags of food put up on the TO GO counter. "McKenna Garage" scrawled. Bishop approaches the counter, reaches over the bags for own food, pushing his drink onto the floor.
I'm sorry. My bad. The guy at the counter shrugs, turns for a mop. Bishop quickly reaches into the McKenna bag, switches a wrapped sandwich for one he brought.
A white van passes the entrance to the underground garage pulls into the Alley behind the building and stops.

Bishop kills the engine, pushes aside a curtain and heads into the back of the van which is empty aside for a heavy acetylene torch. The bottom of the van is covered by a th black matt which Bishop kicks with his foot. The matt falls aside revealing a large HOLE in the bottom the van, right down to the pavement and the welded steel cover Bishop has parked on top of. 23. Bishop picks up the torch, SPARKS IT.
The four SECURITY are eating their delivered lunch. Secur #1 puts a hand to his gut. Security #2 looks over.
Hey, you okay?
Actually, call central. I'm not -- And with that, he's suddenly up and MOVING towards the bathroom. Security #2 raises his radio.

Elevator doors open. Another SECURITY GUARD steps out, checks in by radio and heads down a corridor. IN THE ELEVATOR behind him, Bishop drops through the ceil hatch, dressed casual. He hits a button, doors close.

Elevator doors open and Bishop steps out into the office. Deserted. Monitors glow, tracking markets and trades. But the human element is gone. Except for Harry, alone, silhouetted at one of his large plate windows, watching the sun rise over the city.
You ever wonder what the last day of your life will feel like, Arthur?
You keep standing next to that window, maybe you'll be able to tell me. McKenna looks over, smiles weary. He looks exhausted. He goes to his desk, picks up a tie, looks to Bishop.

Can't se the Mark in the pool from here, but can hear her strokes.

She kicks hard, dives under... And we're in her P.O.V. Th far wall approaching, then we REVOLVE as she turns, now looking UP at the surface as she backstrokes to the surfa BREAKING THE SURFACE, now swimming face up to the bright lights hanging from the girdered ceiling.
The second Guard tests the door. Seems fine. Takes out hi flashlight and plays it over the roof. Sees nothing. We REVERSE to find Steve there, tucked away, just out of sig
The first guard reaches the source of the noise: A plasti bag, caught in a revolving air vent. He pulls it free. 73.

With the Mark, coming out of another turn, still backstro looking up. She makes it half way across the pool... paus She slows... floating, staring upwards into the light. HER P.O.V. The lights. But it's like she senses something beyond them, puts a hand up to shield her eyes...

head_text.subj: AND BISHOP DROPS FROM THE CEILING, FREE-FALL, COMING STRA

text: She opens her mouth to scream... WHUUMPH! He goes in, taking her with him underwater, his momentum carrying them both several feet under. She TWIST in his arms, fighting. Screaming, bubbles FLOWING from he mouth! ABOVE THE SURFACE. It's silent. No sign of the violent struggle going on below the surface. ACROSS THE ROOM. Guard number one returns, glances up towards the pool. Doesn't hear anything. He sits back in his chair. UNDERWATER. The struggle is violent, silent, terrible in it's inevitable conclusion. The Mark writhes and jerks bu Bishop holds her tight, always pulling her away from the surface. Finally, the fight goes out of her. She goes lim in his arms. He turns her, stares into her unseeing eyes. Then lets he go, rising slowly to the surface. AT THE SURFACE. Bishop just breaks, breathing in, silent. He raises himself slightly, sees the guard at his post. ACROSS THE ROOM. The guard glances back towards the pool, hasn't heard anything for a little bit... BAM! BAM! BAM! A new noise from outside gets his attentio again. He heads out, hand on his sidearm...

The guard approaches the same door Guard #2 already check banging in the wind. Open again. He starts to move toward it when a FIGURE looms, he almost draws his weapon, breat relief when he makes Guard #2.
It's the second time it's come open. She still swimming? 74.
The two Guards come into the pool area. On the far wall, shower is running, a towel has fallen over the drain and water is flowing down and into the pool. One of the men steps forward, concerned...
Oh hell... The Mark floats face-up in the pool, just under the surfa

Bishop has already shed his wet clothing, pulls on dry clothes as Steve comes into the room. They barely acknowledge each other, business. Bishop stuffs the wet clothes in a bag, dumps it into a LAUNDRY chute.
How did it go --

Not yet. As if on cue, an ALARM BLARES. Excited voices come on ove an embassy wide PA System. VOICES from the next room. Bishop opens the chute again as Steve cracks a glowstick, puts it between his teeth, swings his legs in, and DROPS. ACROSS THE ROOM. The door to the dressing room opens, arm guards flood in, along with Embassy officials speaking on radios. The room is empty.

Tight, PITCH BLACK except for the eerie glow coming from glowsticks Bishop and Steve have in their teeth. They sli FAST, the sides of the tube RUSHING up at them. And then suddenly a dim LIGHT at the bottom, rising fast...
Steve lands hard in a cart of towels. Rises and pushes himself out of the way just in time for Bishop who grabs pack he tossed down, shoulders it, and they're MOVING aga now through sub-corridors.
Alright, you gotta admire that. You gotta admit, we are a spooky good team... 75. They PUSH through a set of old doors, move fifteen feet t metal roll-down door.
It's like one moment we're there... the next moment... He ROLLS UP the door. STARES at a NEW WALL OF CEMENT BRIC
...we're fucked. Bishop takes in the problem, starts to solve it. He track left right, considering options...

There wasn't any sign of this on the plans. I went over them fifty times!! This isn't supposed to be here! This can't be here! Bishop holds up a finger. "Shhhhhh" They LISTEN. A soft "beeping." Both men PEER around the edge of the metal doo to where a small box with a red light BLINKS.
Bishop... what do we do!?

Duck... Steve looks at Bishop and BOOM! Doors BLOW OPEN, THREE GUARDS burst through, machine guns raised and SPITTING... Steve hits the deck. Watching Bishop, it's like everythin we've seen so far was in slow motion. This is the real thing, unleashed. Bishop WRAPS the first man up, uses his Kevlar vest as a shield to catch the fire from the other two. The man SCRE as his arm breaks. Bishop gets control of his weapon, focuses it on the other two. One is BLOWN back. The other DIVES for cover. Fluid, Bishop REVERSES the man, pushes him AWAY from him, coming up with TWO of the man's Flash-bangs in each hand. Each hand DIALS the grenade's timers to two different settings, simultaneously POPPING the levers. Second attacker FIRES a burst which Bishop DUCKS, the bul stitching across the first attacker, SLAMMING him back, h rounds TEARING into the ceiling, showering Steve in debri Bishop THROWS the first grenade which reaches the attacke just as he rises for another shot. BOOM! 76. Another down as ANOTHER ATTACKER dives through the door a Bishop who wraps the man up, his fingers finding pressure points on the man who goes limp in his arms, dead. ON STEVE. On the floor, witnessing everything. Even in th chaos, recognizing the move. Bishop SHOVES the last grenade down the front of the dead attacker's clothes, wheels him around, PRESSING him again the concrete brick wall... ... TWO more Security kick open a door, guns fire! Bishop goes horizontal, his legs CRUSHING the one man against th metal Grate even as he returns fire at the other two who back and BOOM! The grenade goes off! Bishop is HURLED against the far wall. SMOKE AND DEBRIS fill the space. Bishop MOVES, hauling Steve to his feet and shoving him i the ragged hole blown in the brick wall even as bullets t after them. A bullet catches Bishop in the side, he spraw then LEAPS towards the hole...

Cover in the floor is tossed aside. Bishop and Steve emer move 6 feet to a non-descript Buick. Climb in. The keys a waiting, Bishop starts it up, drives up the ramp. Next to him, Steve is catatonic, lost. As he drives, Bish RIPS a strip from his shirt, pads the wound in his side.
Hey! Hey! You still here?
...It was my fault. I was in charge of the exit. I looked at every work order, every entry in the building logs...

No one controls 100% That's the nature of the beast. Steve swallows, nods as Bishop brings the Buick around a corner, ACCELERATING at the closed gate in front of them, Turkish guard waving his arms frantically...
Firetrucks and ambulances already crowd the streets. Ther just no time or extra manpower left to react to the Buick which plows through the gate of the locked garage. 77.
Two blocks behind, a single police car follows. Bishop ta a hard turn, moving FAST.

Hey! You did good in there. You hear me?. It was asking a lot. You came through. Steve nods, processing, accepting. Another TURN. Bishop slides the car to a stop in a covered lot. Across from th Bishop's own Cobra waits. Behind them, the police car tears by, lost.
Bishop drives down the small lane leading to his home. St is staring out his window, deep in thought. Finally, look over. For the first time takes in Bishop's injuries.
You're bleeding.
...Yup.
So back there. That was one hundred percent? Bishop looks over, gives nothing. Tiny smile.

Door opens and Bishop and Steve come in. Steve plops in a chair, head in his hands. A beat, and then MUSIC filters Neil Young's "Needle and the Damage Done." He raises his head, sees light glowing from the study.
Bishop sits in a chair, eyes closed. Steve comes in, star at Bishop. Looks over and admires the surface of the spinning record...

Do you think you know it, when you've made the mistake you won't survive? Or will it be like the Marks? Wake up on top of the world, never know... 78. Steve glances into the open cabinet where Bishop keeps hi vinyl, FREEZES. Comes out with an signed album.
...Oh my God. This is a signed Hendrix Axis, 1967 release. This has gotta be worth... we have to play this. You have to play this.
(shaking head no) That one... is for a special moment. Haven't found it yet.
You haven't found the... Are you kidding? You have to -- what? Bishop's eyes SHOOT open. He looks out the window where a series of SEDANS are pulling up. Men get out, approach.
This could get... interesting.
Bishop steps out of his home. One of the several men ther steps forward.
Mr. Bishop? Mr. Dean would like a moment of your time. Off Bishop who... nods.
Sedan pulls up, Bishop is escorted onto a private jet.

Steve stands in the middle of Bishop's home. Home alone. -- Steve stares at the classic vinyl on Bishop's turntabl -- Steve, wiring his IPod to Bishop's stereo. Nine Inch Nails' "Piggy" comes blasting out, insults the speakers. -- Steve moves to the bedroom, STARES at the haunting painting. He reaches forward, takes it down. Nothing. Blank wall behind. 79.

Steve blasts in, lights glow on, illuminate the wall of research on the Female Mark. He goes to the gas fireplace flames flicker up. Steve RIPS down the pictures of the woman. Moves to the fire and feeds the first one in. ON STEVE, watching. His eyes... Tracking to the side. STEVE'S P.O.V.: Down, below the fire, stuck to the side o the interior cavity... a scrap of paper... Steve kills the fire, reaches in, carefully removes the s of paper. A corner of a photograph. A few buildings, distant, out of focus. Almost nothing.
Bishop, shirtless, stares in the mirror. He checks the wo in his side, splashes Vodka from a handful of mini bottle painfully re-wraps the wound.
Bishop emerges from the bathroom, peers out at the grey monoliths of Washington D.C., below.

Gray morning. Wind blows. Steve stands alone, holding the scrap of photograph, now in a plastic envelope. He stares where the chalk line has almost completely faded, then lo up, taking in the views, vantage points. A half mile away building under construction rises high.
Bishop steps off the plane. Another sedan and driver wait

P.O.V. THROUGH A CAMERA: The McKenna Holding Corp buildin Image focuses on the rooftop, shutter clicks. Steve lowers the camera, looks at the display. He removes the scrap from Bishop's fireplace, compares it... the sam buildings in the corner of the frame. Perfect match. ON STEVE. No remaining doubt. Bishop killed his father. 80. WIDER. The SECURITY PROFESSIONAL is up here with Steve, hanging back. Steve nods to him.
Do it. I don't care what it costs.
Driver pulls the sedan to a stop in front of a large nondescript building. Bishop steps out, alone on the stre passes through the morning commuters, and goes in.
Bishop passes through a SECURITY CHECKPOINT. Post 9/11, hyper-conscious. Metal detector. Smart guards backed up b battle-ready US Marines. Bishop collects his ID, waits fo door to "click" open.

Bishop sits in a fluorescent lit room, now with a bar-cod badge on his coat. A few other people also wait. Bishop checks his wound, pulls his coat closed to mask where blo has stained his shirt. A door opens and a plain woman nods to Bishop.

Bishop sits in a chair. Through blinds, views of gray DC. WIDER. We realize that the plain woman is sitting across from Bishop, watching him. Finally, the door opens and DE enters. Pasty white, slightly balding. It's hard to locat where the sense of power come from, but it's there, innat He motions to the woman who leaves. Dean sits at his desk taps his fingers on it.
You look like shit.
How does Harry McKenna's son figure in?
He's going to be working with me from now on.
You sure that's wise? 81.
Do I need your permission?

No... And for the record, I don't believe you'd ask for it. Dean grabs a remote control on his desk, points it at the of flatscreens on the wall which hum to life, muted. News reports featuring the killing of the Turkish Embassa Shots of the woman, smiling. Helicopter shots of the pool structure. Words scroll: "Terror on our soil." "Assassination!" "US Envoy ejected from Turkey..."
That was my baby. But my baby has turned into an epic shit-storm and so when the man who caused said epic shit storm suddenly decides to do some soul-searching...
What are you doing, Bishop?
The mistake was mine, not the kid's.
Dean leans in, intense. Bishop watches the screens. A screen changes to a commercial for a Bahamas resort.
I am on some very fucking thin ice right now which means you are on some very fucking this ice as well.

Someone I trained. That could be worth a lot to you. Dean laughs, rises with nervous energy and goes to the interior blinds, raises one. From here they can see out o the office. Glimpses of a dozen conversations. Other men and women at work. More than a couple glance over towards Dean's office. A predatory vibe.
And here I thought we were both going to live forever. Bishop smiles. Dean stares at him. Bishop stares back. Suddenly, this becomes the moment, the decision... 82.
You know, in this business, you only get one mistake. (off the flatscreens) So nothing more like that. You take full responsibility.
Yes. The two men, face to face. Then Dean's phone rings. He turns to it, snaps it up.
Hey, Stanley. Yes, we're all sorted out. I just need you to --
The hit, on the woman. What was the reason? Dean looks back, surprised, angered.
I'm calling you back. Dean clicks off, takes in this change of rules. A dead seriousness infects his voice. Fear.
You know, this foul-up, McKenna's son, it's all got some people's panties in a real twirl.
This isn't the time for questions. This is the time for survival. Everyone... is expendable. Beat. Dean turns away, picks up the phone again.
Yeah, get me Stan again...

Steve lays out by his pool, sunglasses, baking under the as his group of hangers-on swarm around him. Play, dance, splash. He's immune to all of it. Louise climbs from the pool, water drips off her perfect form. She nestles in behind Steve, her hands running over his body. He stares straight ahead, as if she didn't exist. 83.
Come on, baby. What's the matter? Finally, something does catch his attention: At the gate, DHL Van pulling up, the driver heading toward him. Steve lowers his glasses.
Seen from far away, the sedan pulls up. Bishop gets out.
Bishop enters, looks around. No sign of Steve, or any disturbance. He moves through the house.
Steve! Steve...!?
Bishop tense, in his study, holding the phone which rings rings... Steve's voice comes on the voicemail: "Hi, this Steve. You know what to do."

Bishop, sitting on his couch. On the TV in front of him, images from a protest in Turkey, an American flag burning Bishop's eyes flick to the stack of DVDs from the woman. He keeps watching the news images. His phone rings. He snatches it up.
Bishop.
You're still alive.
Seems that way.
Hey, can you meet me? Something I want to talk with you about. Bishop, silent.
It's important. Come up to the house. Please, okay?
Okay. 84.

Bishop's sportscar pulls up in front of the large estate. Bishop gets out, surveys the grounds. Weirdly quiet. The windows of the house, dark. The grounds, empty. He moves to the gates to the back yard, finds them open. pushes through, cautious.
Bishop moves towards the darkened pool area. As he approaches, Steve comes into view, standing by himself on edge of the diving board in the center of the dark space.
There you are. Thanks for coming.

What's on your mind? Steve just smiles, shakes his head. Bishop stares at him, tense, confused. Each trying to read the other. Then Steve raises a bottle of whiskey to his mouth, drink Bishop takes a step forward and... ... LIGHTS WASH THE SPACE! Explosions! SOUND FILLS THE AI

Bishop ducks, rolls, his hand moving under his jacket... ... but not coming out with his gun. He takes in a surpri party, opening in front of him. Beautiful woman, LAUGHING blowing horns. Men, pouring champagne. STREAMERS falling the ground where seconds before they blew into the air, a large BANNER, illuminated behind Steve: "HAPPY BIRTHDAY ARTHUR!" And Steve, standing on the board, master of ceremonies, staring back at Bishop... oddly cool, dispassionate. Then he smiles. Bishop rises. Women come to him, touch him, put a party h on him and give him small kisses with wishes of "Happy Birthday" as he moves to the pool edge across from Steve.
It's not my birthday.
When was the last time you celebrated your real birthday? No response from Bishop. Steve nods, swigs the bottle aga He's lit, something fierce and fiery in his eyes. 85.
See? You're overdue, buddy.
Who are these people?
They think you're a friend of mine, a producer, from Canada.
In other words, they're all your best friends.

Bishop sits on an outdoor sofa, surrounded by several gorgeous aspiring MODELS. Steve sits across from him, Lou under his arm. Bishop watches as one of the models ties a cherry-stem into a knot with her tongue, presents it to t group to a round of applause.
So what movies have you made?
Oh, he makes the really violent, disturbing stuff. You wouldn't know it to look at him, I know, but what's locked up away in there... (tapping his head) Frightening, man.
God, I love those. Which ones --
Mr. KcKenna has a creative relationship with the truth. I don't actually... The model glances around, unsure...
Oh, okay. That's funny. So what do you do?
Yes, Mr. Bishop. What do you do? Bishop doesn't respond. He's just staring down. BISHOP'S P.O.V.: Discarded, lying beneath the sofa the models are perched on: The tear-strip from a DHL Envelope 86.

Come on, Mr. Bishop. We're all waiting. Bishop looks up at Steve who SMILES back. A beat, and the Bishop is up and moving through the crowd, pushing by peo LAUGHING, DANCING. He almost runs into a bright blue-hair woman on the arm of a jockish RAPPER.

Excuse me... He comes up short, realizes he's staring into the face of Woman. She's utterly different than we've seen her. Tonight, she's the clubbing party-girl. Dark lipstick, bright blue wig, heavy eye-liner.
Hi.
Hi... This is strange. The Rapper she's with has found a group of his buddies. H fives all around. He glances around for his date...
Is he your...?
No, just a job. (off his nod) I have to...

I know. Go on. She nods, turns away. He also turns, starts moving throug the crowd, pushing through DANCING BODIES... ... and suddenly she's back with him. No words. Lights an sound and dance around them. She leans forward, kisses Bishop once. Backs off, smiles, turns away and makes her back to the guy she came in with who tucks her under his without missing a beat, mid-story with his posse. Bishop... staring. Turns away as the MUSIC STOPS. Steve's voice fills the outdoor space, amplified.
Ladies and gentlemen! The man of the hour! A SPOTLIGHT hits Bishop. He squints up as the crowd makes space for him. Steve's near the DJ, speaking on a mic. 87.

I know that not many of you know my friend. My good, dear... friend. I mean, he's a man of few words... And he's an art lover! Did you know that? His home is covered with work. It's amazing, what you can find in there. Amazing. A weird beat. Steve, smiling fierce.

Happy birthday, Arthur. Behind Steve, a covered object. Steve now turns to it, pu the cover off a PORTRAIT of Bishop, clearly done by the Artist he collects. The image is twisted, vivid, disturbi As the crowd erupts in APPLAUSE the ARTIST himself now co forward, Steve's arm around his shoulder and bumping fist before the Artist heads on towards Bishop, shaking Bishop hand. Faces BEAM. People CLAP. On Bishop, just looking at Steve who stares back... unreadable.
Bishop bangs out a door into the front drive, makes it to car, fumbles for his keys. Sweating, off-kilter.
Hey, you forgot something. Steve's there, holding the portrait. Bishop nods, takes i
Sorry... Sorry for leaving. I'm just not used to --
No worries, man. It's your party. You can leave it.
It's true, isn't it? What you said to me the first time we met.
What's that?
This thing we do. Finally, you always do it alone. Bishop nods unconsciously, starts towards his car, forces himself to stop. 88.
Steve... thank you.
Uh-oh. I can feel some male bonding coming. We gonna hug it out, Bishop?
No, I'm serious. Thank you. People don't... Anyway, it's been a long time, since someone did something for me. Steve looks back, nods. Strangely dark.
Happy Birthday, Arthur. Steve raises a hand, shoots Bishop with a finger. A wink, and he turns and is gone, back to the party. Bishop climbs into his car, pulls away.

Bishop drives the car out of McKenna's estate, pulls out the street. He starts to accelerate away... then STOPS th car in the middle of the street. ON BISHOP. Fighting what his guts are screaming at him. Losing it, POUNDING on the steering wheel. Suddenly still
Party rages on, oblivious to the absence of its recipient Suddenly faces turn UPWARDS... to where Steve is looking on everyone from a third story balcony over the pool.
Are you all having fun! SHOUTS and NODS. LAUGHTER.

I despise each and every one of you! MORE SHOUTS, LAUGHTER. Steve LEAPS out into space. Perfec huge swam dive... falling... HITTING the water. A moment silence... did he? Was that deep enough...? Steve ERUPTS out of the water. Party ROARS back into life 89.
High above the festivities. Bishop slips over the wall, makes his way down towards the estate.

Dark and empty in here, party raging outside. Bishop ente Steve's bedroom. Messy, the bed unmade. A woman's underthings lying on the floor. Bishop surveys the room, checks drawers, peers down into party below. He can see Steve in the middle of it all, Louise on his arm, his hand on her ass. Bishop moves to the office door, locked. He slides a pick set out of his pocket, gets to work.

The door lock "clicks" and Bishop enters, closes the door after himself and locks it, turns around... The room has been STRIPPED of everything that was in here last time. GONE are the paintings, the portraits, the mementos. All traces of Harry McKenna, removed. Instead, a SINGLE desk inhabits the center of the room, a small computer monitor and keyboard centered on it. Bisho comes around, touches a key on the keyboard. The monitor glows to life with a single "PASSWORD" prompt. Bishop stares at it. He sits, staring, concentrating...
Steve has moved to the edge of the raised patio, looking into the valley. His eyes still, deep, impossible to read
Hey! Hey baby! Karen's got some amazing E. You need to come try... Steve turns those cool eyes on her. She shrinks. We think he might slap her, then:
Give me a moment. I'll be right there. We'll do that amazing E. And he looks away, back down over the view. A resigned loneliness settling into his features. 90.

Bishop, just staring at the password prompt which throbs front of him. Beat. His eyes flick across to the few book lying on the desk. Weaponry, physiology... Greek Mytholog Bishop reaches forward, types "Nemesis." Hits ENTER. A moment... and then our minds are blown. The entire wall of the room in front of Bishop glows to l It's a one large high-resolution monitor. On it, glows an infinitely detailed work-up on Bishop. A photograph on hi glows at the center of the screen, changing every three o four seconds to another. This is Bishop's method, brought into the 21st century. Accounts, Medical charts, psych profile, associates, residence... Bishop approaches... takes it in. Touches "Accounts" and window SPREADS OUT across the whole wall. Multiple window all of Bishop's money, displayed in real time, the number subtly changing with the flow of foreign markets. Another window above is labeled "Associates." Bishop touc this one and the financial windows are replaced with a collage of FACES. Not too many. We recognize the Store Owner and his Daughter. Steve himself. An older man "Gera Bishop," Bishop's father. And a photo of the Woman. Bishop touches the woman and multiple images propagate ou from the single. Many stills, but several are in motion, looping: Childhood movies. A commercial done as a teen. A blue movie when she was 20. Bishop's eyes settle on a vid image: He and the woman, caught just an hour ago in the middle of the dancing party. The woman leaning to him, kissing him. Bishop stares at the image, then touches another image labeled "Residence." INSTANTLY, the images are replaced w images of the interior and exterior of Bishop's home. Bishop stares at them, confused. SQUINTS... realizing tha in one of the images, the trees lightly sway in the breez

Huh. His eyes dart to an image of his DINING ROOM. It looks li a still, until suddenly Bishops' cat passes through the frame. Bishops' eyes dart, moving from frame to frame. Th whole interior of his life. His living room, bedroom, stu gym. All live feeds.
Son of a bitch... 91.

Door BURSTS open, Steve pushing in, his arms wrapped arou Louise and another gorgeous woman from the party. As the women hit the bed, start undressing each other, Steve tak moment -- sensing. Something not right. He pulls keys fro his pocket, unlocks the study door, peers in.
Come on, Steve. We need you.
Low end. Mean men and loose women. Metal on the juke. Duc taped naugahyde. Bartender on parole. Eyes raise as Bisho pushes in, scattered focus, hits the bar.

Whiskey. Neat. Lots of it. Bishop fumbles in his pocket, brings out a thick wad of c $100s and $20s. Eyes track. At a booth, two EX CONS lock onto Bishop, one sporting a middle-finger raised FU tatto his bare shoulder. Bishop pushes $100 forward.
That's too much. Bishop grabs the shot, down it. Pushes the empty shot and the cash back at the bartender.
I'm not going anywhere.

Another shot is put down on the bar, empty. Bishop wipes watery eyes, nods to the bartender to hit it again. Bishop stares at the drink, then his attention is drawn t the bar TV. Footage from the protests in Turkey is narrat by a news anchor, speaking.
...Intelligence services can listen to our calls. But what about the rest of the world?

Well, today the answer seems to be 'No" as outrage over the assassination of the Turkish envoy Bahar Miryem has forced the US to reverse its position, now saying that it will not make it support of Turkey's EU bid contingent on its cooperation in the security agreement. Miryem had always advocated for Turkish autonomy from
Bartender hits a remote, annoyed. Channel changes to a 70 Charles Bronson flick. Bishop blinks, shakes his head... He collects himself, weaves out of the bar. The Ex-Cons watch him go.

Bishop weaves his way into an alley to piss. Relieves himself on a wall. Done, he zips up, turns... WHAM! One of the Ex-Cons catches him across the face with punch. Bishop reels back against the wall.
...More. WHAM! WHAM! Bishop takes the punches, no defense. Face punished. The guy backs off, slightly winded.
Dude, you don't want any more, give us that money. Bishop shakes his head. WHAM! WHAM! Two more hits to the body. Bishop just keeps taking the punishment. Seems to relish it. Spits blood.
Look, I'll give you my money, but you have to promise me you won't spend it all on lipstick and tampons. Ex Con #2 pulls a gun, puts it to Bishop's head.
You wanna die right here, motherfucker? Bishop raises his eyes to the man. Not so drunk after all
...Thank you. 93.

Bishop sits at his dining room table, staring straight ah His face is cut, his flesh swollen. He STARES. If paranoi and loneliness had a face, this is it. REVERSE to find the Artist's portrait of him, hung on the wall across, a surreal and distorted mirror. He chews his food steady, even, acutely aware he's being watched. We LINGER on the small camera eye tucked in the high corn of the room, staring down...

Steve sits half-naked in the office chair, the high-tech illuminated in front of him. In the bed in the other room the two women are asleep, nude, draped over each other. Steve watches Bishop leave his table. He hits a control a the image SHIFTS, picks up Bishop checking his mail, grab a baseball cap from a rack as Bishop moves to his den, settles into a chair facing the television. Can't see his face, just the back of the cap on his head, the tv screen set to white static. He touches a key and the IMAGE ZOOMS on Bishop, moving slightly...
Steve...? Where are you, baby?
The TV purrs static, white flickering light fills the roo We SLOWLY TURN, reversing, to find: The baseball cap, hel up at the top of the chair by a pillow. No sign of Bishop
Bishop moves through shadows. He knows the positions of t cameras, avoids them, heads towards his BARN.

Bishop enters, turns on lights. He threads his way throug his collection of beautiful automobiles until he reaches far wall. He ROLLS up a large steel door... ... revealing a wall, COVERED with his research on Steve. Lots of it, weeks of work. He moves forward to a paper th lists stats about Steve that includes a blank space for "Occupation:" Bishop fills it in: "Mechanic." 94. Suddenly LIGHTS wash across the space. Bishop glances out A VAN is making it's way up the drive.

The wall-sized monitor glows Steve's face as he watches t DHL driver get out, makes his way to the door, knock... Steve's eyes flick to what he can see of Bishop, asleep i the chair. No movement... Steve LEANS FORWARD, interested The DHL Driver knocks again, rings the bell. Still no motion... and then Bishop RISES from the chair, makes his to the door. Steve watches Bishop signing, closing the door and moving into his living room where he opens the package, consider the small jump-drive that slides into his hands. ON STEVE. Watching.

CLOSE on Bishop's weighted RP turntable. The needle comin down... touching spinning vinyl. Stones' "Sympathy for th Devil" croons out. ON BISHOP, tacking up pages, photographs, financials. We don't get a clear look, but some pages are redacted, ther government letterhead. Personnel files, budgets, itineraries. Many stamped "CLASSIFIED." Bishop draws lines, connections. Tosses some pages down, pins others higher. Working it. He backs off, stares through us.
Steve pushes in, looks around, tracks towards the study.
Hello? Bishop? He enters the study, sees the WALL, the night's work. In center, a photograph of Dean, Bishop's boss.
There you are. Bishop is leaning in from outside. Nods to Steve.
So who is he? 95.
...US Government. NSA. Very well protected.
What happened to you?
You should see the other guy. Bishop TOSSES Steve an object, goes back outside. Steve looks at it. A WELDER'S helmet with visor.
Steve comes out to find Bishop working intently on a chem project. He's pouring a black plastic-like substance into shallow mold creating a Quarter-sized object. EXTREME CAR
What's that?

This... is liquid Semtex with a built in combustible. Very volatile. Nice and shiny once it dries. But don't... scratch it. Bishop takes a knife, scratches the surface of the coin-s disc, then backs off, by Steve, back into
